docs.abstract: First of three articles Dropping the Ball: The Decline of School Sports; finds that over last quarter century, public school sports in New York City, and physical education programs that underpin them, have been devalued and cast adrift; reports that budgets for sports programs were slashed in 1970's and were never fully restored; sports facilities, from football fields to basketball gyms, decayed along with many of rest of city's school buildings and then always seem to become last priority for repair; physical education classes were cut in half in early 1990's at most schools; demands by teachers' union that coaches be fairly compensated for many hours they worked led school adminstrators to control costs by cutting sports; concerns about legal liability cast a shadow of caution, from Board of Education down, about physical activity and its inherent risks of injury; photos; charts (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: Hipolito Burgos, a 17-year-old senior at Queens Vocational High School, is an immigrant from the Dominican Republic, co-captain of his school's baseball team and an all-round threat as a catcher, outfielder and batter. And he's a good man with a bilge pump, said his coach, Rob Schimenz. That's an important skill for a ballplayer at Queens Vocational. The team's home field, at a public park about two miles from the school, takes on water like a leaky barge because of a pronounced depression near second base. Shovels, rakes and pumps -- along with bats and balls -- are part of the team's equipment, and making the field playable before games has become part of a captain's job.
